Info Source: Included in a dataset downloaded at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Company is plan administrator. Penalty amount reported in range of $10,001 to $50,000.

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2007 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Description: The Justice Department, in conjunction with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Washington, announced that Colorado-based CH2M Hill Hanford Group Inc. and its parent company, CH2M Hill Companies Ltd. agreed that CH2M Hill Hanford Group committed federal criminal violations, defrauding the public by engaging in years of widespread time card fraud.  In order to resolve CHG's civil and criminal liability, CH2M Hill agreed to pay a total of $18.5 million, commit an additional $500,000 towards accountability systems, consent to a corporate monitor, and to continue actively cooperating with the ongoing fraud investigation.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/ch2m-hill-hanford-group-inc-admits-criminal-conduct-parent-company-agrees-cooperate-ongoing

Description: CH2M Hill Hanford Group Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Colorado-based CH2M Hill Companies Ltd., agreed to pay $1.5 million to resolve allegations that it knowingly submitted false claims and paid kickbacks relating to a contract to operate and manage mixed radioactive waste at the Department of Energy's Hanford Nuclear Site in the state of Washington.
Agency: Energy Department referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/colorado-based-ch2m-hill-agrees-pay-united-states-15-million-resolve-false-claims-act-and

Description: On July 25, 2000, the U.S. Department of Energy issued a Consent Order to CH2M Hill Hanford Group, Inc. relating to quality problems with the procurement of safety class piping for the W-314 Project at the Tank Farm Waste Remediation System at DOE's Hanford site. The contractor agreed to the Consent Order.
Info Source: https://energy.gov/ea/downloads/consent-order-ch2m-hill-hanford-group-inc-ea-2000-09

Description: The U.S. EPA has signed a pair of consent agreements with the U.S. Department of Energy and two contractors to resolve alleged violations of federal asbestos handling regulations at the Hanford Site near Richland, Washington.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/370e71f8fc43470e85257caf005a426e.html

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/ofccp/foia/files/CH2M_Hill_Hanford_Inc_Redacted_final.pdf

Description: Sverdrup Technology, Inc. has agreed to pay $2.5 million to resolve allegations of mischarging the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for work carried out by two laboratories operated by Sverdrup at the Stennis Space Center in Hancock, Mississippi.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2001/August/401civ.htm

Description: Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Bechtel was to pay $357.1 million and Parsons $50 million. The announcement did not indicate how the remaining $40 million payment would be divided among the consultants. Here we assume each paid an equal amount.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20080719151831/http://www.mass.gov/?pageID=cagopressrelease&L=1&L0=Home&sid=Cago&b=pressrelease&f=2008_01_23_big_dig_agreement&csid=Cago

Description: CH2M Hill Plateau Remediation Company (CHPRC), a prime contractor at the Department of Energy's Hanford Site, agreed to pay $3,038,270 to resolve allegations that CHPRC violated the False Claims Act by submitting false and fraudulent small business subcontract reports.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-edwa/pr/ch2m-hill-plateau-remediation-company-agrees-pay-more-3-million-settle-hanford

Description: Four companies which received contracts from FEMA to provide trailers to residents of Louisiana displaced by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita agreed to pay a total of $5 million to resolve multi-district litigation alleging that the trailers contained harmful formaldehyde. The parties did not disclose how much each of the companies was to pay. Here we assume the total was divided evenly among them.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: FEMA Trailer Formaldehyde Products Liability Litigation
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/344786/fema-trailer-mdl-plaintiffs-strike-broad-settlement
